I suspect the era of the dedicated handheld gaming device is starting to come to an end. Smartphones are starting to rip the insides out of this market, just like they have already done to the PND market. (And like they will surely do to the low-end digital camera market, too)
Core confirmed that it will drop in SA as well. Will let you know if I hear anything.

More:  Nintendo made there first quarterly loss in its history, whereafter its stock plunged by **21%**.

And this is the company that "reinvented gaming" just a few short years ago.

@lanceha I suspect (and fear) that what we're witnessing may have even more profound implications than that.  The gaming market as we know it is changing, and I'm not sure that we, as a group, are necessarily going to like the look of gaming a few years down the line.

More grist to the mill:  In the middle of this interview…

http://www.industrygamers.com/news/ea-ceo-consoles-now-only-40-of-games-industry/

… Riccitiello states that in 2000, consoles accounted for 80% of the gaming industry.  (By profits?  Unit sales?  He doesn't say.)   Today?  Just 40%.

More pressing:  The decline of game sales year-on-year for the past few years.  (You can find those stats anywhere.)  This is usually painted as a decline in *boxed* sales, but I'm convinced that digital sales of traditional games account for less than a drop in the bucket (though if you have stats to the contrary, do let me know).

But yes, it's hard to read the slashing of price by a ⅓ just 5 months after launch as anything but a massive admission of defeat by the company that has *always* dominated the handheld gaming market.  Heck, these guys barely broke a sweat when then-industry dominator Sony entered said market…

I know this is selfish, but I'm happy to see Nintendo on the defensive again. They've neglected a lot while they've been in cruise mode. Also, expect them to talk to the press a lot more often now. Ha!
I wonder if they'd have the same issue if the 3DS had more than just one game.

We can always hope that the problem really is something as simple as a sparse software library, and not something endemic to the industry as a whole…

Also, that stock plunge was originally misreported.  It was in fact 12%.  Still big for a one-day drop, but not quite as outrageous.
